case_name: M/s. Kasturilal Ralia Ram Jain v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 105 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 105 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 18, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 67 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 18, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 67 of 1950.

facts.text: Appellant is a firm Ms. Kasturilal Ralia Ram Jain dealing in bullion and other goods at Amritsar, registered under Indian Partnership Act, Ralia Ram one of partners.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm which deals in bullion and other goods at Amritsar. It was duly registered under the Indian Partnership Act. Ralia Ram was one of its partners.

facts.text: On 20th September 1947, Ralia Ram arrived at Meerut by Frontier Mail about midnight to sell gold, silver and other goods.

anchor.surface_text: On the 20th September, 1947 Ralia Ram arrived at Meerut by the Frontier Mail about midnight. His object in going to Meerut was to sell gold, silver and other goods in the Meerut market.

facts.text: Ralia Ram taken into custody by three police constables while passing through Chaupla Bazar.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst he was passing through the Chaupla Bazar with this object, he was taken into custody by three police constables.

facts.text: Belongings of Ralia Ram searched and taken to Kotwali Police Station, detained in lock-up.

anchor.surface_text: His belongings were then searched and he was taken to the Kotwali Police Station. He was detained in the police lock-up there

facts.text: Gold weighing 103 tolas 6 mashas and 1 ratti, and silver weighing 2 maunds and 6 1/2 seers seized from Ralia Ram and kept in police custody.

anchor.surface_text: and his belongings which consisted of gold, weighing 103 tolas 6 mashas and 1 ratti, and silver weighing 2 maunds and 6 1/2 seers, were seized from him and kept in police custody.

facts.text: On 21st September 1947, Ralia Ram released on bail.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st September, 1947 he was released on bail,

facts.text: Silver seized from Ralia Ram returned to him some time after release.

anchor.surface_text: and some time thereafter the silver seized from him was returned to him.

facts.text: Ralia Ram made repeated demands for return of gold, not recovered, filed suit against State of UP for return of gold or value Rs. 11,075-10-0 plus Rs. 355 interest.

anchor.surface_text: Ralia Ram then made repeated demands for the return of the gold which had been seized from him, and since he could not recover the gold from the police officers, he filed the present suit against the respondent in which he claimed a decree that the gold seized from him should either be returned to him, or in the alternative, its value should be ordered to be paid to him. The alternative claim thus made by him consisted of Rs. 11,075-10-0 as the price of the gold and Rs. 355 as interest by way of damages as well as future interest.

facts.text: Gold taken into custody by Head Constable Mohammad Amir, kept in police Malkhana under his charge.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent alleged that the gold in question had been taken into custody by one Mohammad Amir, who was then the Head Constable, and it had been kept in the police Malkhana under his charge.

facts.text: Mohammad Amir misappropriated the gold and fled to Pakistan on 17th October 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Mohd. Amir, however, misappropriated the gold and fled away to Pakistan on the 17th October, 1947.

facts.text: Case under section 409 IPC and s.29 Police Act registered against Mohd. Amir, but could not apprehend him.

anchor.surface_text: He had also misappropriated some other cash and articles deposited in the Malkhana before he left India. The respondent further alleged that a case under section 409 of the Indian Penal Code as well as s. 29 of the Police Act had been registered against Mohd. Amir, but nothing effective could be done in respect of the said case because in spite of the best efforts made by the police department, Mohd. Amir could not be apprehended.

facts.text: Trial Court found negligence by police officers and decreed Rs. 11,430-10-0 in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court found in favour of the appellant on both these issues, and since the gold in question could not be ordered to be returned to the appellant, a decree was passed in its favour for Rs. 11,430-10-0.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed trial court, found no negligence or state not liable even if negligent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the correctness of this decree by an appeal before the Allahabad High Court and it was urged on its behalf that the trial Court was in error in regard to both the findings recorded by it in favour of the appellant. These pleas have been upheld by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted certificate from High Court for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court and it is with the said certificate that it has come to this Court by an appeal.

facts.text: Material facts leading to seizure of gold not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts leading to the seizure of gold are not in dispute.

facts.text: Mohammad Amir fled to Pakistan without delivering keys or permission.

anchor.surface_text: He swears that Mohammad Amir who was in charge of the Malkhana, had fled away to Pakistan without delivering the keys to any one and without obtaining permission for leaving his post of duty.

facts.text: Malkhana checked, considerable properties missing, gold not found.

anchor.surface_text: The Malkhana was accordingly checked and it disclosed that considerable properties kept in the Malkhana were missing. On the 26th October, 1947, Ganga Prasad returned the silver articles to the appellant. Gold was, however, not found in the Malkhana,

facts.text: No list of seized goods forwarded to officials, valuables not kept in treasury.

anchor.surface_text: No list of these goods was forwarded to any officials. This witness further added that valuables are generally kept in the wooden box and the key is kept by the officer-in-charge of Malkhana. The gold and silver articles seized from the appellant had not been kept in that box in his presence. He could not explain why the said gold and silver articles were not kept in the Treasury.

facts.text: Seized gold and silver not kept in Malkhana in presence of Mohd. Umar.

anchor.surface_text: He swears to the seizure of the gold and silver articles from Ralia Ram and deposes to the fact that they were not kept in the Malkhana in his presence.

facts.text: No list prepared of seized goods, unsure if precautions taken.

anchor.surface_text: This witness admitted that no list was prepared of the seized goods and he was not able to say whether proper precaution were taken to safeguard the goods in the Malkhana.

facts.text: Police officers negligent in not depositing gold in treasury as per Regulation 166 U.P. Police Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that gold and silver which had been seized from Ralia Ram had to be kept in a separate box under lock and key in the Treasury and that, admittedly, was not done in the present case.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds police officers grossly negligent in handling seized property.

anchor.surface_text: Thus considered, there can be no escape from the conclusion that the police officers were negligent in dealing with Ralia Ram's property after it was seized from him. Not only was the property not kept in safe custody in the treasury, but the manner in which it was dealt with at the Malkhana shows gross negligence on the part of the police officers.

facts.text: Loss of gold due to negligence of police officers employed by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the trial Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the loss suffered by the appellant by the fact that the gold seized from Ralia Ram has not been returned to it, is based on the negligence of the police officers employed by the respondent

as well as s. 29 of the Police Act had been registered against Mohd. Amir, but nothing effective could be done in respect of the said case

holdings.text: Police officers were negligent in dealing with Ralia Ram's property after it was seized from him, showing gross negligence.

anchor.surface_text: Thus considered, there can be no escape from the conclusion that the police officers were negligent in dealing with Ralia Ram's property after it was seized from him. Not only was the property not kept in safe custody in the treasury, but the manner in which it was dealt with at the Malkhana shows gross negligence on the part of the police officers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Violation of U.P. Police Regulations 165 and 166 by not depositing gold in treasury, no list prepared, no weighing, evidence from witnesses shows failure to safeguard property.

holdings.text: Loss of gold is based on the negligence of the police officers employed by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the trial Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the loss suffered by the appellant by the fact that the gold seized from Ralia Ram has not been returned to it, is based on the negligence of the police officers employed by the respondent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court finding on negligence correct, confirmed by evidence and regulations violation.

holdings.text: Gold and silver seized had to be kept in a separate box under lock and key in the Treasury per Regulation 166, which was not done.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that gold and silver which had been seized from Ralia Ram had to be kept in a separate box under lock and key in the Treasury and that, admittedly, was not done in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Regulation 166 U.P. Police Regulations requires valuables in treasury unless Magistrate directs otherwise.

holdings.text: The respondent State is not liable to compensate the appellant for the loss caused by negligence of police officers.

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether the respondent, the State of Uttar Pradesh, is liable to compensate the appellant, M s. Kasturilal Ralia Ram Jain for the loss caused to it by the negligence of the police officers employed by the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Art. 300(1), liability same as pre-Constitution Province; no suit would lie as negligence in sovereign function.

holdings.text: Negligence in custody of seized property is referable to sovereign powers of arrest, search, and seizure; thus no state liability.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers under CrPC ss.54,51,550 are sovereign; Peninsular doctrine applies: no action for torts in exercise of sovereign powers.

holdings.text: Under Art. 300(1), State's liability determined by whether suit competent against corresponding Province pre-Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This question essentially falls to be considered under Art. 300(1) of the Constitution... whether such a suit would have been competent against the corresponding Province

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of Art. 300(1) refers to like cases as Dominion/Provinces; no relevant legislation enacted.

holdings.text: Distinction between sovereign powers (no liability) and non-sovereign acts (liability applies).

anchor.surface_text: there is a great and clear distinction between acts done in the exercise of what are usually termed sovereign powers, and acts done in the conduct of undertakings which might be carried on by private individuals without having such powers delegated to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle from Peninsular & Oriental case (1861), consistently followed.

holdings.text: Vidhyawati case distinguishable: jeep driving not sovereign power.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Driving jeep for Collector not referable to sovereign powers, unlike police seizure custody.

holdings.text: Legislatures should enact laws like Crown Proceedings Act 1947 to regulate state immunity in tort.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy suggestion; UK Act modifies immunity; current law unsatisfactory for citizens.

anchor.surface_text: Thus considered, there can be no escape from the conclusion that the police officers were negligent in dealing with Ralia Ram's property after it was seized from him. Not only was the property not kept in safe custody in the treasury, but the manner in which it was dealt with at the Malkhana shows gross negligence on the part of the police officers.
